availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Mississippi River city in Warren County, Mississippi. By 1840, Vicksburg had grown into the state's second largest city, second only to Natchez. A popular steamboat stop, Vicksburg was a hub of both the slave trade and Mississippi River commerce. As a Confederate river port, Vicksburg was also crucial to Civil War military strategy. After a failed attempt, Union troops defeated Confederate troops on the outskirts of the city and entered Vicksburg on July 4, 1863.

bibl.p: Ownby, Ted and Charles Reagan Wilson, eds., The Mississippi Encyclopedia (Jackson: University Press of Mississippi, 2017), 1302, https://books.google.com/books?id=HWolDwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=vicksburg+mississippi+in+encyclopedia+of+mississippi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj2zMKZlNfVAhXCSyYKHYD-Aa4Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=vicksburg&f=false (accessed 14 Aug 2017).
